comments.commentBody:
If anything, this article goes on to prove what I, and many other commenters have been stating all along -- Polls are the least efficient way of foretelling the results of an election.
In the end, the only thing that matters is your VOTE!
So use it -- don't lose it.

“Statistics are often used like a drunk uses a lamp post – for support, not illumination.” Vin Scully

With tip of the hat and "Thank you" from a Giants' fan...

Just goes to show how difficult accurate polling is....and this article doesn't even get into the landline/cell-phone issue.

Bottom line....it's almost impossible to get a sample that actually matches who votes on Election Day.

When it comes to Trump, the usual margin of error does not make sense -- because (a) he is running a maverick campaign where the usual rules do not apply, and (b) very few Trump voters will openly say that they will vote for him.

That Donald Trump, the WORST candidate in the history of the U.S., is in a tie with Hillary Clinton tells us all we need to know: That, in fact, Hillary Clinton may be the WORST candidate in the history of the U.S.

So why doesn't the Times insist on more honest "margin of error numbers" in polls it sponsors much less those it publishes? Every adjustment made to "correct" the results based on perceived differences between the sample and the population increases the margin of error and this increase can be expressed mathematically. Even though you cannot tell if the error is random or systematic (i.e.bias) you COULD insist that the published margin of error include ALL error, not just that inherent in the ratio of sample size to total sample.  I suspect that if margin of errors were more honestly disclosed a lot of "surprise" results would not be different from the "expected" result within the margin of error.

An obvious question is: what happens if the pollsters allow conscious or unconscious bias to affect the model they choose? And what if even how the raw data is collected is determined by some other model or approach, and that model or approach is likewise subject to bias?

I wonder against whom any such bias might exist in this election.

Nate Cohn has outdone himself on this one. Excellent work.

He captured with a small, elegant test exactly what I’ve been explaining to family and friends for the entire election cycle so far – most poll results differ because of modeling/weighting rather than actual differences in responses. (Now I can just send them a link to this article instead of taking the time to explain it in my own words. Thanks.)

Beyond the issues that are inherent in modeling a voting population, there are variations introduced by the data gathering method (online vs. telephone, landline vs. cell), languages (English only vs. English/Spanish), potential social bias, and others issues.

I’m not even sure that averaging poll results is even valid, considering the herding tendency.

It's a tough year to follow and interpret poll results. Regardless of who wins, November 9th will be a very enjoyable and interesting day for wonks of all stripes.

replies.commentBody:
Let's call it like it is. A majority who will vote for Trump are not college educated and lack analytical skills. (Note I said "a majority" but I'm sure someone will respond as if I said "all"). They do not take the time to actually read or think critically, and respond to world situations with knee-jerk emotion.
They are mirror images of Trump.

comments.commentBody:
More important than the polling variations, how could it be that someone with Hillary Clinton's experience is running neck and neck against a guy with no experience in government, with the any and all so called elite institutions fighting against him?

I mean, did you watch 60 Minutes on Sunday and experience that nuke scaremongering? How about today's military confirmation hearings on C-Span where pretty much every senator emphasized loudly that the President is the only person who can pull the trigger without consent from anyone.

Really folks? We have such a lemon that we need to unleash everyone with a mic to scare the public to vote for her?

Oh yes. We do.

Actually, if the results are considered as a single group, one can easily conclude that Clinton has a slight lead in the sampled group.  This is why no single poll is considered the answer, they need to be considered in aggregate.  Here the difference is that the data for one poll was examined 5 times, as opposed to 5 different polls, but a clear picture emerges.
AG is right. Poling is the scourge of democracy. It injects hysteria and bias into the political circus, and is used to manipulate elections.

What this tells me is that most polling is useless. Given that it does a disservice to the national debate and turns the campaign into a two-year long sports event, it would be good for polling to essentially disappear. Ordinary people can hasten the demise by giving arbitrary and random answers if they are ever polled by pollsters.

replies.commentBody: I take your point, but statistics IS modeling, unless you're only talking about descriptive statistics.
Best model is Princeton Election Consortium.....

comments.commentBody:
What this article shows is that polling is much more about modeling than statistics. Most pollsters build mathematical models of the electorate, separating us into various categories and then assigning properties to each. They then have the task of assigning each actual person in the poll to a category, or dividing them up among categories. The results are then dependent not only on statistical effects, but also on the accuracy of the models.

Just like the stock market, past performance is no guarantee of future accuracy in making predictions. And, unlike the weather, which is a complex phenomenon which is governed by known physical laws, polls depend on an understanding of human psychology, perceptions and emotions that are largely irrational and subject to whimsical change. It should not be surprising then that political polls yield disparate conclusions in tight races like this one.

Mr. Cohn's analysis is fascinating. It reminds me of the science of meteorology, predicting the weather. We are much better at it than decades ago with our sophisticated computer modeling skills but we know that weather like election forecasting is affected by unknown events and trends. We don't know what we don't know.

And also like weather forecasting, when most of the models agree, the odds of those predictions being correct go up and prove accurate...but not always.
